Stephanus de Gabrielli |term_start=February 929|term_end=15 March 931 |predecessor=[[Pope Leo VI|Leo VI]] |successor=[[Pope John XI|John XI]] |birth_date=??? |birth_place=[[Rome]], [[Papal States]] |death_date=c. 15 March 931 |death_place=[[Rome]], [[Papal States]] |other=Stephen}} '''Pope Stephen VII''' ({{lang-la|Stephanus PP. VII}}, {{lang-it|Stefano VII}}; died c. 15 March 931)<ref>Archibald Bower, ''The History of the Popes: from the foundation of the See of Rome to A.D. 1758'' (1845), pg. 311</ref> was the [[Pope|head]] of the [[Catholic Church]] from February 929 to his death in 931. A candidate of the infamous [[Marozia]], his pontificate occurred during the period known as the [[Saeculum obscurum]]. ==Biography== Stephen was a Roman<ref>{{Citation | last = Platina | first = Bartolomeo | authorlink = Bartolomeo Platina | title = The Lives of the Popes From The Time Of Our Saviour Jesus Christ to the Accession of Gregory VII | publisher = Griffith Farran & Co. | location = London | pages = 247-248 | volume = I | year= 1479 | url = http://www.archive.org/details/thelivesofthepop01platuoft | accessdate= 2013-04-25. }}</ref> by birth, the son of Theodemundus,<ref name="m189">Mann, pg. 189</ref> and perhaps a member of the [[Gabrielli]] family.{{Citation needed| date=November 2011}} He was elected—probably handpicked—by [[Marozia]] from the [[Tusculani]] family, as a stop-gap measure until her own son [[Pope John XI|John]] was ready to assume the chair of [[Saint Peter]]. Prior to his election, Stephen had been the [[cardinal-priest]] of [[Basilica di Sant'Anastasia al Palatino|St Anastasia]] in [[Rome]].<ref name="m189"/> Very little is known about Stephen’s pontificate. During his two years as pope, Stephen confirmed the privileges of a few religious houses in France and Italy.<ref name="m189"/> As a reward for helping free Stephen from the oppression of [[Hugh of Arles]], Stephen granted Cante di Gabrielli the position of papal governor of [[Gubbio]], and control over a number of key fortresses.<ref>Collegio araldico, ''Rivista, Volume 5'' (1907), pg. 49</ref> Stephen was also noted for the severity with which he treated clergy who strayed in their morals.<ref>DeCormenin, Louis Marie; Gihon, James L., ''A Complete History of the Popes of Rome, from Saint Peter, the First Bishop to Pius the Ninth'' (1857), pg. 287</ref> He was also, apparently, according to a hostile Greek source from the twelfth century, the first pope who went around clean shaved whilst pope.<ref>Mann, pg. 190</ref> Stephen died around 15 March 931, and was succeeded by [[Pope John XI]]. ==References== * Mann, Horace K., ''The Lives of the Popes in the Early Middle Ages, Vol. IV: The Popes in the Days of Feudal Anarchy, 891-999'' (1910) * {{CathEncy|wstitle=Pope Stephen (VII) VIII}} {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.archelaos.com/popes/details.aspx?id=140 Stephen VII] {{s-start}} {{s-rel|ca}} {{s-bef|before=[[Pope Leo VI|Leo VI]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Pope]]|years=928–931}} {{s-aft|after=[[Pope John XI|John XI]]}} {{end}} {{Popes}} {{Catholicism}} {{History of the Roman Catholic Church}} {{Authority control |VIAF= |GND=100961444 }} {{Persondata |name=Stephen VII |alternative names= | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Pope Pope |date of birth= |place of birth= [[Rome]], [[Papal States]] |date of death= 931 |place of death= [[Rome]], [[Papal States]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stephen 07}} [[Category:Popes]] [[Category:Italian popes]] [[Category:10th-century archbishops]] [[Category:Bishops of Anagni]] [[Category:931 deaths]] [[Category:People of medieval Rome]] [[Category:10th-century Italian people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]
